CSS Combinators ( > , + , ~ )

Let's explore the 3 CSS Combinators:

  • aa > bb : selects a 'bb' element that is a child (at the child level only) of an 'aa' element. (green)
  • aa + bb : selects a 'bb' element that is a next sibling of an 'aa' element. (red)
  • aa ~ bb : selects a 'bb' element that is a general next sibling of an 'aa' element. (violet)

Example #1.
The rule applied is: #div-1 > p {
background-color: greenyellow;
} The combinator acts on the next div, which contains 2 'p's, then 1 'a' which contains 1 'p' in itself, then 1 'nav' with a 'p' inside and finally 2 'p's. As you can see, the background-color is applied only to the first 2 'p's.

This is div with id 'div-1'. A green background-color is applied to any p child of '#div-1'. Note: applies only to children of '#div-1'!

p1 in div-1

p2 in div-1

This text is inside a 'p', which is inside an 'a', in '#div-1': this 'p' is then not a direct child ('>') of #div-1, so it is not selected by #div-1 > p!

This text is inside a 'p', which is inside a 'nav': again, it is not selected by the '>' combinator.

this is selected, since it is a 'p' which is a direct child of '#div-1'.

As you can see, it doesn't matter if the ps are not the next element: they can be anywhere inside '#div-1', but they must be children, not nephew or else.

Example #2. This is '#div-2'. #div-2 + p {
background-color: red;
}

Next sibling of #div-2. Was selected by #div-2 + p

Example #3. This is '#div-3'. #div-1 ~ ul {
background-color: violet;
}

  • this 'ul' was selected by #div-1 ~ ul
  • yesss

A sibling of #div-1. Not affected by #div-1 + p, since it is not the next to it.

  • this 'ul' was selected by #div-1 ~ ul as well
